sections.purpose: To describe the standard operating procedure for the operation of Gas Chromatography (GC) for separation and quantitative analysis of volatile and semi-volatile pharmaceutical compounds.
sections.scope: Applicable to gas chromatography analysis activities carried out in the Central Instrumentation.
procedure: Verify that carrier gas cylinders have adequate pressure and all gas lines are leak-free.
Check that the detector gases (hydrogen, air for FID) have sufficient supply if applicable.
Power ON the GC system including injector, column oven, detector, and data system.
Set the carrier gas flow rate according to the analytical method specifications.
Set the injector, column oven, and detector temperatures as per the method.
Allow the system to stabilize at set temperatures for at least 20-30 minutes.
Verify baseline stability on the detector before starting analysis.
Check column conditioning and perform conditioning run if the column is new or idle.
Prepare sample and standard solutions in appropriate volatile solvents.
Load sample vials in the autosampler or prepare for manual injection.
Inject a blank solvent to verify system cleanliness and baseline stability.
Inject standard solutions to establish calibration and verify system suitability.
Set the temperature program including initial temperature, ramp rate, and final temperature.
Inject sample solutions and monitor the chromatogram during the run.
Ensure proper peak separation, retention times, and peak shapes.
After analysis, allow the column to cool down to initial temperature.
Clean the injection port liner if necessary and replace septa regularly.
Power OFF the detector and then the column oven following proper shutdown sequence.
Document all chromatographic parameters, retention times, and peak areas in the record.
precautions: Always check for gas leaks using leak detection solution before operation.
Never allow carrier gas flow to stop while the column is at high temperature.
Ensure samples are free from particulates and non-volatile residues.
Use appropriate septum quality and replace regularly to prevent leaks.
Do not exceed the maximum temperature limit of the column.
Use flame arrestors on hydrogen lines for safety.
Ensure proper ventilation when using volatile solvents and samples.
Wear appropriate PPE including lab coat, gloves, and safety goggles.
Perform regular maintenance of septa, liners, and detector components.
